maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: LSASS Process Monitor. The core process (lsass.exe) for Active Directory Domain Services is consuming a lot of CPU resources.
If the overall CPU utilization on the server is too high, users and services that rely on Active Directory Domain Services may experience delays.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The domain controller needs resizing.
The domain controller is a bridgehead server, and it is compressing large amounts of data because a bulk load must be replicated inter-site.
The domain controller is a primary domain controller (PDC) emulator operations master, and there are either a large number of password lockouts or a large number of expired user accounts.
One or more other domain controllers failed, and their load transferred to this domain controller because it is now the closest available domain controller.
An application is placing a heavy load on the domain controller. This is usually caused by inefficient, CPU-intensive operations such as non-indexed queries.
The domain controller is critically low on memory.
The domain controller is under a denial-of-service attack.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the overall system performance of the machine to determine if it needs additional resources.
Add additional domain controllers to help load-balance the load.
Ensure that there are a sufficient number of DCs in the active AD sites.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Capacity Planning for Active Directory Domain Services

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Asynchronous Thread Queue (ATQ) Average Threads Monitor. The number of ATQ threads in usage is high which could impact throughput of client requests.

There is a fixed number of available threads for servicing requests. The default and recommended configuration is 4 per processor core. If all threads are in use, additional requests will sit in the queue until a thread is available.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The domain controller needs resizing.
One or more other domain controllers failed, and their load transferred to this domain controller because it is now the closest available domain controller.
An application is placing a heavy load on the domain controller. This is usually caused by inefficient, CPU-intensive operations such as non-indexed queries.
The domain controller is critically low on memory.
The domain controller is under a denial-of-service attack.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the overall system performance of the machine to determine if it needs additional resources.
Add additional domain controllers to help load-balance the load.
Ensure that there are a sufficient number of DCs hosting DNS.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Capacity Planning for Active Directory Domain Services

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: DNS Process Monitor. The DNS process for Active Directory Domain Services Integrated DNS is consuming a lot of CPU resources.
If the overall CPU utilization on the server is too high, DNS requests may be delayed.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The domain controller needs resizing.
One or more other domain controllers failed, and their load transferred to this domain controller because it is now the closest available domain controller.
An application is placing a heavy load on the domain controller. This is usually caused by inefficient, CPU-intensive operations such as non-indexed queries.
The domain controller is critically low on memory.
The domain controller is under a denial-of-service attack.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the overall system performance of the machine to determine if it needs additional resources.
Add additional domain controllers to help load-balance the load.
Ensure that there are a sufficient number of DCs hosting DNS.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Capacity Planning for Active Directory Domain Services

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors the number of items in the AD Replication queue. If this number becomes too large, there may be a delay in AD replication.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The domain controller is undergoing initial replication post promotion.
The domain itself has undergone a lot of changes and created a large number of objects to be replicated.
The replication topology is not optimal and needs to be reconfigured.
An application is placing a heavy load on the domain controller. This is usually caused by inefficient, CPU-intensive operations such as non-indexed queries.
The domain controller is critically low on memory.
The domain controller is under a denial-of-service attack.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the overall system performance of the machine to determine if it needs additional resources.
Add additional domain controllers to help load-balance the load.
Ensure that there are a sufficient number of DCs in the active AD sites.
Run 'repadmin /showrepl' and 'repadmin /replsum' to ensure there are no replication failures with other domain controllers.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Troubleshooting Active Directory Replication Problems
How Active Directory Replication Topology Works

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: AD Log File Free Space Monitor. Monitors that the free disk space on the drive that contains the AD log file is below the minimum acceptable level.
If the disk drive is full, Active Directory Domain Services will not function correctly and will cause failures for the services that use it.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The database size has grown through normal use of the directory.
Other files have been placed on this drive recently.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Relocate unnecessary files to an alternate volume or extend/replace the volume involved.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: AD Database Free Space Monitor. Monitors that the free disk space on the drive that contains the AD database (DIT) is below the minimum acceptable level.
If the disk drive is full, Active Directory Domain Services will not function correctly and will cause failures for the services that use it.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The database size has grown through normal use of the directory.
Other files have been placed on this drive recently.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Relocate unnecessary files to an alternate volume or extend or replace the volume involved.
Perform an offline defrag on the AD database.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information, see:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Introduction to Administering the Active Directory Database
Performing offline defragmentation of the Active Directory database

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Global Catalog Search Availability Monitor. This monitor performs a Global Catalog search.
If the search fails, an alert will be generated.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Interval: default 300 seconds

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An attempt to search the global catalog failed.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the alert data for additional information.
If the script failed to perform a search, verify that Active Directory Domain Services is in a healthy state using dcdiag.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Capacity Planning for Active Directory Domain Services

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Global Catalog Search Response Monitor. This monitor measures the time that is required to perform a Global Catalog search.
If the average search time over the specified number of samples is above the configured threshold, an alert will be generated.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Interval: default 300 seconds
Warning Threshold: default 5 seconds
Error Threshold: default 10 seconds
Number of Samples: default 3

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An attempt to search the global catalog took longer than the specified threshold.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the alert data for additional information.

If the search time is above the configured threshold, view the overall system performance of the machine to determine if it needs additional resources and also ensure that there a sufficient number of DCs in the active AD sites.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Capacity Planning for Active Directory Domain Services

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Agent Proxy setting is required for the AD Topology discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Agent Proxy Security setting is disabled to one or more Domain Controllers.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: In the console under Administration -> Agent Managed. For each Domain Controller managed node select Properties -> Security -> Agent Proxy. Select the check box.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule runs the AD Monitor Trusts script. The script makes a call to the TrustMon Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) provider, which is available in Windows Server 2003 and newer, to check trust relationships.
Communication between domains and forests occurs through trust. Trusts are authentication pipelines that must be present in order for users in one domain to access resources in another domain.
If a trust is broken, communication between the forest and/or domain will be blocked which may prevent users and services from accessing critical resources.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Interval (sec) default 300.

maml:listItem.maml:para: One or both domains cannot resolve FQDN of the other domain.
Network connectivity between domains is malfunctioning.
Trust is miss configured in one or more domains.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Please review the alert details for additional information and look-up the related error codes.
Verify the trust status using the Active Directory Domains and Trusts MMC Snap-in.
Verify that the domain is resolvable through DNS by running 'nslookup [name]'.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Active Directory Domains and Trusts

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: AD Replication Partner Count monitor. This monitor verifies that the domain controller has a suitable number of replication partners.
If the number of replication partners is too low or high, the overall replication health may be affected.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Interval (sec) default: 300
Number of connections warning threshold - default 40. If the number of connections (either inbound or outbound) is greater than this number then an alert is raised.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Alerts raised indicate that this domain controller has an unusually high number of replication partners and is in danger of not being able to replicate in a timely fashion.
If the domain controller does not have any inbound or outbound replication partners, it will not be able to pull or push changes.
This alert is commonly triggered by another domain controller failing, which causes the Knowledge Consistency Checker (KCC) to compute new optimal replication paths.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: In this case, fix the failing domain controller and review your replication topology design to prevent future overloads in the event of a domain controller failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor verifies that the domain controller is successfully replicating with all of its inbound replication partners.
If it fails replication for any of its inbound partners AD data could become inconsistent between domain controllers.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Interval (sec)
default: 300 sec (5 min)
Max Replication Latency (min)

All Naming Contexts should replicate within an hour unless specifically configured otherwise in AD. The default is 65 min to allow for minor delays. Depending on your Active Directory topology, this threshold may need to be tuned appropriately.
Max Replication Latency RootDSE (min)

The RootDSE should replicate within a few minutes as this is the NC that changes the most. Since the RootDSE replicates so often this control was added to allow for tighter replication thresholds for the RootDSE. By default the replication threshold is set to 15 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Alerts raised indicate that this domain controller has had an issue replicating with one or more of its replication partners.
If the domain controller fails replication for one or more naming contexts in AD, its data (i.e. User/computer accounts and passwords, etc) may become stale and out of date.

This alert could fire while one of the other Domain Controllers in the forest is being rebooted or having maintenance performed on it. This is mitigated by verifying that the DC responds to ping or not but we expect a few false negatives to fire from this monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Log on to the Domain Controller experiencing issues and run diagnostics to help determine why replication failed. The following diagnostic commands are helpful in diagnosing replication failures:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Repadmin /ShowRepl
Repadmin /replsum
dcdiag /test:Intersite
dcdiag /test:KccEvent
dcdiag /test:ObjectsReplicated
dcdiag /test:Replications
dcdiag /test:VerifyReplicas

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: TechNet guide for troubleshooting Active Directory replication problems

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule is used to collect events that are related to naming collisions for the AD Duplicate Accounts report.
When a collision of this type occurs, multiple accounts share the same name. It is then impossible for the Active Directory directory service to distinguish which of the accounts the name refers to.
Sample Event:

Attempt to update DnsHostName and HOST Service Principal Name (SPN) attributes of the computer object in Active Directory failed because the Domain Controller '%1' had more than one account with the name '%2' corresponding to this computer. Not having SPNs registered may result in authentication failures for this computer. Contact your domain administrator who may need to manually resolve the account name collision.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Manually change one of the account objects to a unique name.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information, see:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Security Accounts Manager (SAM) encountered an error while attempting to allocate memory. If this persists, look for other out-of-memory conditions.
Sample Event:
The attempt to check whether group caching has been enabled in the Security Accounts Manager has failed, most likely due to lack of resources. This task has been rescheduled to run in one minute.
Related Events:
This event has a matching 'success' event that indicates that the error condition no longer exists. The 'success' event is: 'The group caching option has now been properly updated' (event id 12300)

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Schedule a reboot for this computer at the first available opportunity. To escalate issues with memory leaks and use of this process, contact Microsoft Product Support Services.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: While trying to build a Kerberos ticket, the Key Distribution Center (KDC) detected two user objects with the same user principal name (UPN). The KDC cannot determine which user object is correct; therefore, it cannot create a ticket.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Users and Computers Microsoft Management Console (MMC) snap-in checks for this problem and attempts to prevent it from occurring. However, the following situations can create this condition:

maml:listItem.maml:para: A script that is being used to create users is not checking for uniqueness.
A Microsoft Windows NT 4.0 utility is being used to create users.
A meta-directory or other provisioning tool that is being used to create users is not checking for uniqueness.
Replication is slow or malfunctioning.
A denial-of-service attack is under way.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Change the UPN on one of the conflicted user objects using the Users and Computers snap-in.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information, see:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: UserEnv experienced an error applying Group Policy to the domain controller. Group Policy must be applied successfully for domain controllers to function properly because domain controllers get several critical permissions, such as Access this computer from network, through policy.
Because of the architecture of UserEnv, Microsoft Operations Manager (MOM) is unable to directly report the specific problem.
Sample Event:
Windows cannot determine the associated site for this computer. (%1). Group Policy processing aborted.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To enable UserEnv logging, see Knowledge Base article 221833, How to Enable User Environment Debug Logging in Retail Builds of Windows at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=25636. The log file provides details for the specific error.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This domain controller has received an invalid Authentication Service (AS) request from the primary domain controller (PDC). It is possible that someone is attempting to spoof the PDC for the domain.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that this domain controller can communicate with the PDC by reviewing the alerts created by the AD Op Master Response script.
Verify that there is no firewall blocking the Kerberos port.
Reset the password on the machine account for the PDC.
Use Adsiedit.msc to verify that the PDC machine account does not have a user principal name (UPN) defined.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information, see:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: When updating a policy class, the Key Distribution Center (KDC) encountered invalid policy data and has failed to update the policy.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Contact Microsoft Product Support Services for support.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information, see:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: UserEnv experienced an error applying Group Policy to the domain controller. Group Policy must be applied successfully for domain controllers to function properly because domain controllers get several critical permissions, such as Access this computer from network, through policy.
Because of the architecture of UserEnv, Microsoft Operations Manager (MOM) is unable to directly report the specific problem.
Sample Event:
Windows cannot query for the list of Group Policy objects. Check the event log for possible messages previously logged by the policy engine that describes the reason for this.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This may indicate that the Active Directory directory service has failed. Problems with replication are the main cause of this error.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To enable UserEnv logging, see Knowledge Base article 221833, How to Enable User Environment Debug Logging in Retail Builds of Windows at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=25636. The log file provides details for the specific error.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: An error occurred during application of machine security policy to the domain controller. Because this policy grants permission to replicate (as well as other permissions), this problem must be resolved to ensure successful replication.

UserEnv experienced an error applying Group Policy to the domain controller. Group Policy must be applied successfully for domain controllers to function properly because domain controllers get several critical permissions, such as Access this computer from network, through policy.
Because of the architecture of UserEnv, Microsoft Operations Manager (MOM) is unable to directly report the specific problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: See Winlogon.log for information concerning the specific policy failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: UserEnv logging may also provide information about this problem. To enable UserEnv logging, see Knowledge Base article 221833, How to Enable User Environment Debug Logging in Retail Builds of Windows at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=25636. The log file provides details for the specific error.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Windows cannot allocate memory.
Contact your administrator. (%1).

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Schedule a reboot for this computer at the first available opportunity. To escalate issues with memory leaks and use of this process, contact Microsoft Product Support Services

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: AD Connection Object Monitor. This monitor sets the health state for a connection object. The state is determined as bad, or error if the Connection Object is considered to be in that state. This monitor uses attributes set by the AD Remote Topology Discovery, which actually determines the state.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Interval (sec) default 300.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: AD Remote Topology Discovery discovered bad connection objects

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify your site configuration

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: Discovery Rules cannot set health state in the Operations Manager console, so this monitor has to be used to translate the discovered property into a state.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor verifies the availability of Active Directory using an LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) request. It periodically binds to the Domain Controller to verify the availability using an LDAP query.
This monitor allows for monitoring of non-SSL, SSL, and both types of bindings.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor provides the following on configuration:
IntervalSeconds: How frequently the monitor is run (seconds)
MonitorBindType: 1) Non-SSL, 2) SSL, 3) Both

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: An incorrect number of arguments are being passed to the script.
The domain controller is not setup to allow LDAP binds over SSL however the monitor is trying to perform them.
The domain controller needs resizing.
The domain controller is a bridgehead server, and it is compressing large amounts of data because a bulk load must be replicated inter-site.
The domain controller is a primary domain controller (PDC) emulator operations master, and there are either a large number of password lockouts or a large number of expired user accounts.
One or more other domain controllers failed, and their load transferred to this domain controller because it is now the closest available domain controller.
An application is placing a heavy load on the domain controller. This is usually caused by inefficient, CPU-intensive operations such as non-indexed queries.
The domain controller is critically low on memory.
The domain controller is under a denial-of-service attack.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the error description in the alert for additional information.
View the overall system performance of the machine to determine if it needs additional resources.
Add additional domain controllers to help load-balance the load.
Ensure that there are a sufficient number of DCs in the active AD sites.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Capacity Planning for Active Directory Domain Services

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor verifies the availability of the PDC FSMO using a basic ping request. It periodically pings the Domain Controller to verify the availability.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: IntervalSeconds: How frequently the monitor is run (seconds)

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The domain controller is offline.
The domain controller has a misconfigured network adapter.
DNS is failing to resolve the domain controller properly.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the domain controller is online and functioning correctly.
Ensure that DNS is properly resolving the domain controllers IP address.
Attempt to ping another domain controller from the FSMO holder itself.

maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the domain controller is online and functioning correctly.
Ensure that DNS is properly resolving the domain controllers IP address.
Attempt to ping another domain controller from the FSMO holder itself.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor verifies the availability of the PDC FSMO using a basic ping request. It periodically pings the Domain Controller to verify the availability.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: IntervalSeconds: How frequently the monitor is run (seconds)

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The domain controller is offline.
The domain controller has a misconfigured network adapter.
DNS is failing to resolve the domain controller properly.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the domain controller is online and functioning correctly.
Ensure that DNS is properly resolving the domain controllers IP address.
Attempt to ping another domain controller from the FSMO holder itself.

maml:section.maml:para: This monitor verifies the availability of the PDC FSMO using a basic ping request. It periodically pings the Domain Controller to verify the availability.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The domain controller is offline.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor verifies that the PDC and the local DC agree on which server holds the Domain Naming Master FSMO role.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: IntervalSeconds: How frequently the monitor is run (seconds)

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: There is an AD replication problem in the domain.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the domain controller is online and functioning correctly.
Ensure that DNS is properly resolving the domain controllers IP address.
Check that dcdiag is not returning any problems.
Check that repadmin is not showing any problems with AD replication.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor verifies that the DNS servers for all network adapters resolve to ping requests.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: IntervalSeconds: How frequently the monitor is run (seconds)
Error Threshold: threshold that must be exceeded to trigger an error alert
WarnThreshold: threshold that must be exceeded to trigger a warning alert

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The DNS servers are not reachable.
There is a problem with one or more network adapters.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the DNS Servers for all network adapters are correct.
Ensure that the DNS Servers for all network adapters are online and functioning correctly.
Ensure that there are no problems with the network adapters.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor verifies that replication is consistent across your Domain Controllers.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: IntervalSeconds: How frequently the monitor is run (seconds)
TimeoutSeconds: How long before the monitor will timeout (seconds)

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Replication failing between Domain Controllers

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the domain controller is online and functioning correctly.
Ensure that DNS is properly resolving the domain controllers IP address.
Check that dcdiag is not returning any problems.
Check that repadmin is not showing any problems with AD replication.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the DNS Servers for all network adapters are correct.
Ensure that the DNS Servers for all network adapters are online and functioning correctly.
Ensure that there are no problems with the network adapters.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor verifies the availability of Active Directory using an LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) request. It periodically binds to the Domain Controller to verify the availability using an LDAP query.
This monitor allows for monitoring of non-SSL, SSL, and both types of bindings.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor provides the following on configuration:
IntervalSeconds: How frequently the monitor is run (seconds)
NumSamples: How many times the monitor has to be over the threshold to generate an alert
ThresholdWarnSec: The warning threshold in seconds
ThresholdWarnError: The error threshold in seconds
MonitorBindType: 1) Non-SSL, 2) SSL, 3) Both

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: An incorrect number of arguments are being passed to the script.
The domain controller is not setup to allow LDAP binds over SSL however the monitor is trying to perform them.
The domain controller needs resizing.
The domain controller is a bridgehead server, and it is compressing large amounts of data because a bulk load must be replicated inter-site.
The domain controller is a primary domain controller (PDC) emulator operations master, and there are either a large number of password lockouts or a large number of expired user accounts.
One or more other domain controllers failed, and their load transferred to this domain controller because it is now the closest available domain controller.
An application is placing a heavy load on the domain controller. This is usually caused by inefficient, CPU-intensive operations such as non-indexed queries.
The domain controller is critically low on memory.
The domain controller is under a denial-of-service attack.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the error description in the alert for additional information.
View the overall system performance of the machine to determine if it needs additional resources.
Add additional domain controllers to help load-balance the load.
Ensure that there are a sufficient number of DCs in the active AD sites.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Capacity Planning for Active Directory Domain Services

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitor that watches the number of Active Directory's Lost and Found objects. If the number of Lost and Found objects is beyond the specified threshold, the monitor health state will change accordingly.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Interval default 300 seconds.
Threshold default is 15 objects..

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Replication issues between DCs.
Time Sync is off for DCs.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Evaluate every object in the CN=Lost and Found container under the root domain and delete or move objects appropriately.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Troubleshooting Directory Data Problems

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: AD Time Skew Monitor. This monitor generates an alert when the time difference between the local domain controller and a target domain controller exceeds a specified threshold.
This means that two domain controller disagree about the current time. If the time skew grows too large, Kerberos authentication can be affected.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Interval - default 5 minutes (300 seconds).
Alert Threshold - default 2 minutes (120 seconds).
Retry Iterations - default 3 times.

Target Server - the target DC which the time will be compared against. The target DC should be one that is configured to sync time with an external, reliable time source. By default, this will be the PDC.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: PDC not configured to use external time source
Multiple DCs configured to use different external time sources

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify each DC is syncing from either the PDC or a Gtime server. Verify that which ever DC all other DCs are syncing time from is set to use an external time source.
You can use the command line tool w32tm.exe to configure time on the DCs. See external resources below.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information, see:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: How the Windows Time Service Works
Troubleshooting Windows Time Service Problems
Configuring Time service for the forest

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Microsoft Windows Server 2016 AD Monitoring Management Pack
Purpose

The Microsoft Windows Active Directory Management Pack provides forest-wide monitoring of the Active Directory directory service and its required subsystems. In addition to real-time performance and event monitoring, this Management Pack provides automated and customizable response capabilities, which you can use to respond immediately to critical performance, health, or capacity issues.

Featuring extensive Active Directory knowledge and links to the most up-to-date information sources, the intent of this Management Pack is to provide value, and reduce the cost, effort, and skills required to manage Active Directory.
You can use the information in this Management Pack, to manage Active Directory, and identify potential issues before they become critical.
Features

The Active Directory Management Pack provides the features you need to manage your Active Directory environment, including automated discovery, health monitoring and recovery, and replication monitoring. The extensive embedded knowledge in this Management Pack enables you to manage your Active Directory environment, increasing availability, security, and performance. For example, this Management Pack alerts you to the following critical conditions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Active Directory replication fails.
The global catalog is not available.
Active Directory is not responding.
Domain Name System (DNS) is not available.

maml:section.maml:para: This Management Pack includes views that you can use to centrally monitor the health, performance, and availability of your Active Directory environment. You can use views such as the following to instantly begin managing your Active Directory environment to provide an immediate return on your investment:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Available Disk Space on Windows Domain Controllers
Active Directory Database
Replication Traffic Bandwidth used

maml:section.maml:para: This Management Pack also provides automated rules to monitor the performance and health of essential Active Directory functions, including the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Primary domain controller (PDC) emulator master availability
Replication latency or queue size
Available disk space for drive hosting the Active Directory database

maml:section.maml:para: These rules gather data on speed, capacity, and availability. You can easily analyze this performance information by using the Active Directoryspecific reports that are included in this Management Pack. You can use these reports to perform accurate load balancing and capacity planning and to alert you to possible future problems. In addition, there are reports, diagram views, and tasks that:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Track availability of domain controllers and key Active Directory services.
Provide details about domain topology and information about trusts, replication topology, and location of operation masters.
Provide information about possible replication problems.

maml:section.maml:para: Configuration
Because DNS is such a vital component of Active Directory, it is recommended that you also install the Microsoft Domain Name Service Management Pack.
It is also recommended that you install the Windows Operating Systems Management Pack.
After initial installation of the Active Directory Management Pack, you will need to configure the following items:
Determine the maximum acceptable replication latency across your forest, that is, the maximum amount of time that you are willing to wait for changes to arrive at any given domain controller.
To set the replication monitor to this maximum replication latency, override the Replication Latency Threshold for the rule: AD Show Replication Check

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor verifies that Group Policy is successfully being applied to the domain controller.
It will perform a 'gpupdate' operation per the specified configuration interval.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: IntervalSeconds: How frequently the monitor is run (seconds)

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: There is a misconfigured Group Policy object.
There is a problem with SYSVOL.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the domain controller is online and functioning correctly.
Check that dcdiag is not returning any problems.
Check the External links to troubleshoot the specific Group Policy failure that is in the alert.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information, see:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Troubleshooting Group Policy Problems
Troubleshooting Group Policy Using Event Logs

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: No input to sync time provider is available. See alert description for details.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Kerberos failed to verify the signature on the Privilege Attribute Certificate (PAC) field in the Kerberos ticket from the Key Distribution Center (KDC). This indicates that the PAC field was modified.
This is significant because the PAC field is used to store the users token. It is possible that someone is attempting to break into your system.
In rare circumstances, it is possible that a memory problem on a router corrupted the packet during transmission.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the ticket-granting service (TGS) reply packet originated from the KDC. If it did not, investigate a possible attempt to break in to your system.
If the packet did originate from the KDC, reset the machine account password for the KDC.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information, see:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: An invalid Group Policy setting has been configured for this Key Distribution Center (KDC).

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Using the Group Policy Object Editor, check the policy settings for:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Maximum Service Ticket Age
Maximum Ticket Age
Maximum Renew Age

maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the values are not 0 or larger than allowed. Also, check the max clock skew to ensure it is not too large.

This rule is disabled by default because it can be very noisy in large environments and there are many reasons why a machine account may fail authentication. Override this alert to start capturing these events.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary

Sample Event:

Attempt to update DnsHostName and HOST Service Principal Name (SPN) attributes of the computer object in Active Directory failed because this computer account name, '%2' could not be mapped to the computer object on Domain Controller '%1'. Not having SPNs registered may result in authentication failures for this computer. Contact your domain administrator. The following technical information may be useful for the resolution of this failure: DsCrackNames status = 0x%3, crack error = 0x%4.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Contact Microsoft Product Support Services for assistance.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This domain controller was not able to obtain the account identifier from the relative ID (RID) operations master.
Sample Event:

The account-identifier allocator was unable to assign a new identifier. The identifier pool for this domain controller may have been depleted. If this problem persists, restart the domain controller and view the initialization status of the allocator in the event log.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Determine which domain controller is the RID master, and verify that this domain controller can contact it.
If this problem persists, restart the domain controller and view the initialization status of the allocator in the event log.

Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule creates a report that shows important changes to the domain. Use the AD Domain Changes report to view these changes. Changes that are reported include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Operations master changes
Conversion to native mode
Booting to restore mode

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The purpose of this rule is allow for the Domain Changes Report to be generated while turning off the alerts notifying you that it was generated. This can help reduce the noise generated by the AD MP.
To have the report generated without a corresponding alert being generated disable the 'Create Domain Changes Report and Alert' rule and enable this rule 'Create Domain Changes report'.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: UserEnv experienced an error applying Group Policy to the domain controller. Group Policy must be applied successfully for domain controllers to function properly because domain controllers get several critical permissions, such as Access this computer from network, through policy.
Because of the architecture of UserEnv, Microsoft Operations Manager (MOM) is unable to directly report the specific problem.
Sample Event:
Windows cannot find the machine account, %1.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Possible causes include:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The computer has been restarted. If it is determined that this was the cause of the alert, simply resolve the alert.
The computer might be running out of available memory.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: For more information, see the UserEnv log file. UserEnv logging is not enabled by default. To enable UserEnv logging, see article 221833, How to enable user environment debug logging in retail builds of Windows in the Microsoft Knowledge Base at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=25636. The log file provides details about the specific error.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Windows cannot query the list of Group Policy objects (GPO) because the number of GPOs has exceeded a maximum limit.
Sample Event:

Windows cannot query the list of Group Policy Objects because the number of GPOs has exceeded a maximum limit. Contact your network administrator to reduce the number of Group Policy Objects applied to you.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Reduce the number of GPOs that are applied to you.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Windows cannot access the registry policy file.

UserEnv experienced an error applying Group Policy to the domain controller. Group Policy must be applied successfully for domain controllers to function properly because domain controllers get several critical permissions, such as Access this computer from network, through policy.
Because of the architecture of UserEnv, Microsoft Operations Manager (MOM) is unable to directly report the specific problem.
Sample Event:
Windows cannot access the registry policy file, %1. (%2).

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Either the Registry.pol file is not accessible on SYSVOL or the file is corrupt.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To enable UserEnv logging, see Knowledge Base article 221833, How to Enable User Environment Debug Logging in Retail Builds of Windows at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=25636. The log file provides details for the specific error.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This domain controller is unable to set its time because it is more than 15 hours out of sync with its time provider.
Sample Event:
The time service has not been able to synchronize the system time for %1 seconds because none of the time providers has been able to provide a usable time stamp. The system clock is unsynchronized.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the time provider has the correct time. If the time provider has the correct time, manually adjust the time on this domain controller to the correct time.
Run W32tm once at a command prompt to verify that the time can now synchronize.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary

Windows cannot determine the user or computer name. (%1). Group Policy processing aborted.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To enable UserEnv logging, see Knowledge Base article 221833, How to Enable User Environment Debug Logging in Retail Builds of Windows at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=25636. The log file provides details for the specific error.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: Knowledge Base article 221833, How to Enable User Environment Debug Logging in Retail Builds of Windows at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=25636
For more information, see:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The operating system cannot obtain a domain controller name.
Sample Event:
Windows cannot obtain the domain controller name for your computer network. (%1). Group Policy processing aborted.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: There was a problem with NetLogon. Look for other NetLogon errors to help diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Look for NetLogon errors to help diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information, see:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: UserEnv experienced an error applying Group Policy to the domain controller. Group Policy must be applied successfully for domain controllers to function properly because domain controllers get several critical permissions, such as Access this computer from network, through policy.
Because of the architecture of UserEnv, Microsoft Operations Manager (MOM) is unable to directly report the specific problem.
Sample Event:
Windows is setting registry value %1 to %2.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To enable UserEnv logging, see Knowledge Base article 221833, How to Enable User Environment Debug Logging in Retail Builds of Windows at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=25636. The log file provides details for the specific error.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: Knowledge Base article 221833, How to Enable User Environment Debug Logging in Retail Builds of Windows at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=25636
For more information, see:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Microsoft Help and Support for Microsoft Windows Server
Microsoft Knowledge Base

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: The health of the Sysvol shared folder is essential to the Domain Controller. Sysvol is a shared folder on every domain controller that stores a copy of the domains public files, including system policies and Group Policy settings, which are replicated to all other domain controllers in the domain. SYSVOL share problems prevent Group Policy and login scripts from working.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the DFS Namespace service is running on this domain controller. This service enables you to group shared folders located on different servers into one or more logically structured namespaces.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The DFS Namespace service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the DFS Namespace service is set to automatic start and is running.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the DFS Replication service is able to successfully register the WMI providers. If this operation fails, replication will be disabled until the problem is resolved.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The DFS Replication service is not able to successfully register the WMI providers.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) service is set to automatic start and is running.
Check the Application and System event logs to ensure that there are no systemic problems with the server.
Perform WMI and DFS Replication troubleshooting per the links below.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information, see:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Troubleshooting Problems with WMI Scripts and the WMI Service
Troubleshooting Dfsr Problems

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the Active Directory Domain Services service is running on this domain controller.
If the service is stopped, users will be unable to log on to the network.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Active Directory Domain Services service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the Active Directory Domain Services service is set to automatic start and is running.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the DFS Replication service is running. If SYSVOL is set to use DFSR and the service is stopped, Group Policy updates will not take place until the service is started.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The DFS Replication service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the DFS Replication service is set to automatic start and is running.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that SYSVOL is currently sharing on this domain controller.
If SYSVOL is not sharing, clients and services will not be able to obtain Group Policy information from this domain controller.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: SYSVOL is not sharing.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the domain controller is fully synchronized. SYSVOL will not share until the domain controller has finished its initial synchronization post DC promotion.
Check the DFSR or NTFRS event logs to ensure the File Server services are working correctly.
Check the Application and System event logs to ensure that there are no systemic problems with the server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the Inter-site Messaging service is running on this domain controller. This service enables messages to be exchanged between computers running Windows Server sites.
If the service is stopped, messages will not be exchanged, nor will site routing information be calculated for other services.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Inter-site Messaging service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the Inter-site Messaging service is set to automatic start and is running.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the Kerberos Key Distribution Center service is running on this domain controller. This service enables users to log on to the network using the Kerberos authentication protocol.
If the service is stopped, users will be unable to log on to the network.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Kerberos Key Distribution Center service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the Kerberos Key Distribution Center service is set to automatic start and is running.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the Netlogon service is running on this domain controller. This service maintains a secure channel between this computer and the domain controller for authenticating users and services.
If the service is stopped, the computer may not authenticate users and services, and the domain controller cannot register DNS records.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Netlogon service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the Netlogon service is set to automatic start and is running.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the server is able to successfully use DCLocator to find a suitable domain controller in the domain.
If DCLocator fails, the server will not be able to communicate with the domain.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: DCLocator is unable to find a suitable domain controller.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: From an elevated command prompt, run "nltest /dsgetdc:" to ensure DCLocator is functioning correctly.
Check the Application and System event logs to ensure that there are no systemic problems with the server.

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: DFSR and NTFRS are essential services for a Domain Controller. It is required that one or both of these services be running, depending on the state of file replication migration.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: DFSR and NTFRS are essential services for a Domain Controller. It is required that one or both of these services be running, depending on the state of file replication migration.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The NTFRS service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Go to service manager and start the NTFRS service

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the Windows Time service is running on this domain controller. This service maintains date and time synchronization on all clients and servers in the network.
If the service is stopped, date and time synchronization will be unavailable.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Windows Time service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the Windows Time service is set to automatic start and is running.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the Group Policy Client service is running on this domain controller. This service is responsible for applying settings configured by administrators for the computer and users through the Group Policy component.

If the service is stopped, the settings will not be applied and applications and components will not be manageable through Group Policy. And components or applications that depend on the Group Policy component might not be functional if the service is stopped.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Group Policy Client service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the Group Policy Client service is set to automatic start and is running.
Check the Application and System event logs to ensure that there are no systemic problems with the server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the DNS Client service is running on this domain controller. The DNS Client service (dnscache) caches Domain Name System (DNS) names and registers the full computer name for this computer. If the service is stopped, DNS names will continue to be resolved. However, the results of DNS name queries will not be cached and the computers name will not be registered. If the service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The DNS Client service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the DNS Client service is set to automatic start and is running.
Check the Application and System event logs to ensure that there are no systemic problems with the server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the Active Directory Web Services service is running on this domain controller. This service provides a Web Service interface to instances of the directory service that are running locally on this server.
If the service is stopped, client applications, such as Active Directory PowerShell, will not be able to access or manage any directory service instances that are running locally on this server.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Active Directory Web Services service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the Active Directory Web Services service is set to automatic start and is running.
Check the Active Directory Web Services event logs to ensure that the service is operating correctly.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitors that the Domain Name Server (DNS) service is running on this domain controller. This service enables DNS clients to resolve DNS names by answering DNS queries and dynamic DNS update requests.
If the service is stopped, DNS updates will not occur.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Domain Name Server (DNS) service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the DNS Server service is set to automatic start and is running.
Check the DNS Server event logs to ensure that the service is operating correctly.

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: The health of the Sysvol shared folder is essential to the Domain Controller. Sysvol is a shared folder on every domain controller that stores a copy of the domains public files, including system policies and Group Policy settings, which are replicated to all other domain controllers in the domain. SYSVOL share problems prevent Group Policy and login scripts from working.

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: Go to http://search.microsoft.com/, Search the Microsoft Knowledge Base for articles.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The DC Disk Space chart report displays one chart with these performance items:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Database Size - AD Storage
Log File Drive Free Space - AD Storage
Database Drive Free Space - AD Storage

maml:section.maml:para: The report finds data if the objects supplied are of type
Active Directory Domain Controller Computer Role
Search for objects which contain their NetBIOS Name
The report displays for every selected object a separate chart. Data is not aggregated
When run from the Reporting space:
The second column in the search results shows of which type the displayed objects are. Make sure you select objects of type Active Directory Domain Controller Computer Role.
When run from the Monitoring space:
Create a state view or performance view by choosing the Active Directory Domain Controller Computer Role type.
Date/Time selection: Allows selecting a relative or fixed date and time range and time zone.
Object: Allows adding objects to run this report for
